title: High Power LED mini Lamp Shade

description.text:
This lamp shade holds "star" type high power LEDs to make economical lighting fixture.
With a handy little controller, you can install LED lighting everywhere easily & economically.
I have a LED controller that's perfect for this kind of project. Please find the information at instructables (http://www.instructables.com/id/Universal-High-Power-LED-Driver-with-3D-printable-/).
Print, wire the LED and press fit into the base of the shade.

title: "Arduino RF433 controller via Ethernet" project case with Batman/Joker theme

description.text:
This is a project case that I designed for a DIY Arduino Ethernet RF433 controller.

It is constantly listening to commands sent from my smartphone over ethernet and will switch on/off various lights in my residence. It also drives RF controlled mains relays and other DIY Arduino LED strip projects.

In order to use this you will need a few special components, and some soldering skills:

  • Sparkfun Arduino Pro Mini
    https://www.sparkfun.com/products/11113

  • RF433 transmitter
    http://www.icstation.com/433mhz-transmitter-receiver-arduino-project-p-1402.html

  • Mini ENC28J60 Ethernet LAN Network Module
    http://www.ebay.com/itm/Mini-ENC28J60-Ethernet-LAN-Network-Module-For-Arduino-51-AVR-SPI-PIC-STM32-LPC-G-/272138979501

There are various libraries to drive these components, such as:

  • For the RF433 module: Radiohead
    https://github.com/PaulStoffregen/RadioHead

  • For the Microchip ENC28J60: Ethercard
    https://github.com/jcw/ethercard

Since the RF433 modules have better range at 12v, I have added a 12 DC-DC step down switching converter (Traco TRS 12450) to convert 12v to 5v. The ENC28J60 however requires 3.3v so I also added a 3.3v linear voltage regulator. However, for some reason the ENC28J60 works fine without logic level conversion so I am using 5v logic. All of this can be packed neatly on the connector board, which you'll have to solder yourself.

title: Support pour fixe l'ordinateur PC Stick de chez Archos

description.text:
Voici un support pour fixer l'ordinateur PC stick de chez Archos.

Il est fait pour le montage dans un bateau, je vais le mettre sous la table a carte, comme cela, il ne bougera pas.

J'ai fais en dessous un V pour une meilleur ventilation.

Pour le mettre ou le retirer, il suffit de dévisser les 2 molettes, le mettre et les re visser.

Il n'y a besoin que de deux boulons de 4mm tête hexagonal, puis bien sur 2 vis pour le fixer ou vous avez besoin.

print_settings.Notes:: I tried to make some parts not need supports.

description.text:
So this model was made by me. This is my second model. What I did was work out the cylinder barrel size and roughly designed the rest of this prop relative to that size. Some sizes will be off, I did modify the look of it a bit. It is ready to have 40 mm dummy grenades fit into it. It is intended to have moving parts.

The grip and picatinny I took off thingiverse just to show an example. Those models are not included in this print.

You will need a spring to put under the topclip (lever)
You will need a bolt and bearing to hold the barrel cylinder.
Some parts need gluing together.
You will need bolts to or pins to secure the hinge system.

I didn't orientate the parts as some of you may like to print the parts in different orientation.

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCnUgkBmiQfixJcNUzDw5YWA
https://www.facebook.com/AandPcreative/

This is a Positioner (Incra Style) with a MakerSlide Profile for an Table Saw or Router Fence. All Parts are printed in PLA but ABS will work also. All Parts can be printed separately or in compbination (for example Part 1,2 & 3 or Part 6 & 7). All Parts are screwable with countersunk M3x15 (5x) . You need also 2 springs 6x15mm and 4mm x120mm Steel or Brass Rod. If you print all Parts separately, glue Part 1, 2 and 3 - glue Part 6 and 7.
Parts are designed in Sketchup. I printed 3 Positioner in different designes until all Parts matched perfectly.

Old part was printing fine so nothing to worry about for those who managed to print it already.

This is the remix of Paper Towel Holder made by areeve20.

Original item had both legs the same height and when one of the legs is slid into the bracket one side turns out to be 5mm higher making paper towel sit on the lean.

So in my remix I've only redesigned bracket by removing bottom bit and adding slightly larger sides to accommodate screw holes.

Done it by editing existing STL file using SketchUp.

I was considering leaving the bracket as is and extend one of the legs but went with the bracket at the end.
Why?
I'm pretty sure that there are some other people who already printed original Towel Rail and this could be a quick fix (aka less filament/time to get it in level)

Enjoy.

description.text:
Pulsador de una cisterna de pared empotrada. Estas cisternas se encuentran en varios colegios públicos pero han quedado descatalogadas por lo que ciertos repuestos como este pulsador ya no se pueden conseguir.
.
El pulsador mide 137mm de alto, pero mi impresora daba menos medida por eso cree el fichero "pulsador_cist137.6.stl". En cualquier caso puedes descargarte el fichero ".scad" y ajustarlo para otras medidas.
.
El diseño ya lleva incluido los soportes que una vez terminada la impresión se pueden eliminar pero también se incluye una versión sin los soportes.
.
El "remache.stl" sirve para introducirlo en el lateral sobre el que se imprime la pieza y sirve para que ambos laterales queden iguales y el pulsador quede centrado.

This is my torch holder. I designed it to compliment my Parametric Battery Dispenser (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15149) and it mounts to the inside of a cupboard door for convenient access. The design is sized to fit a LED Lenser M7 Torch but is highly parametric so can be used with just about any torch. I am sure that it could be used to hold many other tools as well. I designed it to use double sided sticky foam to attach to the inside of a cupboard door but I have also included options that create mounting holes either horizontally or vertically. This as well as the mounting plate being fully parametric (You can choose between two corner styles as well), means I am confident that the design will suit many tastes. The clasp part of the holder is also parametric so you can choose a thickness and also opening size that suits your materials and printer capabilities. The default values work well printed in PLA at 35% infill, 3 skins. This seems to be flexible enough that the torch can be pulled through the clasp without damaging the finish of the torch or stressing the plastic. YMMV In the pipeline are a host of other door mounting fittings, I intend to organise all my most often used tools in this manner.

• Download the openscad file.

  • Adjust the variables at the start of the file to create your preferred dimensions and style of Parametric Torch Holder

  • Export the stl to your favourite slicer and print.
    • Variables The Clasp Dimensions
    torch_diameter
    clasp_height
    clasp_thickness
    opening_angle
    arm_length
    arm_width The Back Plate Dimensions
    plate_rounded_opt
    plate_corner_radius
    plate_depth
    plate_width
    plate_height Mounting Hole Dimensions
    mount_holes_opt

Die Csword 90 Korvette.
Habe sie nach den wenigen Bildern und Daten aus dem Netz nachgebaut. Alle OBJ oder STL Daten sollten am 3D Drucker doppelt so gross ausgedruckt werden. Die Details lassen sich sonst nicht mehr ausdrucken. Wenigstens auf meinem Drucker nicht. Der Maßstab ist dann ca. 1:200. Die Länge des Schiffes ist in etwa 55cm, die Höhe 22cm und die Breite 10cm. Die Antennen habe ich aus 0,4 mm Silberdraht gefertig. Die Ruderwellen aus Holzzahnstochern.
Die Bilder könnt ihr im Netz finden. Wegen Copyright habe ich diese hier nicht ausgestellt.
Das ganze wurde wieder mit Sketchup 2015 erstellt.
Eine graphische Übersicht findet ihr in csword2.skb. Dort sind auch die einzenen Segmente zur besseren Übersicht markiert.
Ich wünsche allen Interessenten viel Spass damit.
Grüsse an alle.
Den Hubschrauber habe ich von RAH-66 Comanche
by TheVNPrinter, published Oct 18, 2013.

The Csword 90 Corvette.
Have they rebuilt after the few images and data from the network. All OBJ or STL data should be printed out twice as big on 3D printers. The details can be otherwise no longer print. At least on my printer not. The scale is then about 1 in 200. The length of the vessel is approximately 55cm, the height of 22cm and width of 10cm. The antennas I gefertig from 0.4 mm silver wire. The rudder shafts wooden toothpicks.
The pictures can you find on the net. Because of copyright I have this not exhibited here.
The whole was re-created with SketchUp, 2015.
A graphical overview can be found in csword2.skb. There the einzenen segment for clarity are marked.
I wish all those interested have fun with it.
Greetings to all.
The helicopter I of RAH-66 Comanche
by TheVNPrinter, published Oct 18,, 2013.

Sub millimeter calibration pattern. Each line is slightly translated by 0.1 mm offset. Find the line that best match the other line, count the offset from the center (the long line), multiply it by 0.1 and update the software.
The squares give you an indication of offsets that are greater than 1 mm. The box with the cross gives you another very good offset indication.

Edit September 2016: Version 2 of this ready, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1728791

Make pictures like on Google Streetview !

After seeing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1459595 and loving the design I thought of doing something more automaticly. I had some ESP8266 Witty boards laying around (http://nl.aliexpress.com/item/ESP8266-serial-WIFI-Witty-cloud-Development-Board-ESP-12F-module-MINI-nodemcu/32566502491.html) I wanted the GoPro to be automaticly making the pictures, so I want to use the WiFi of it together with two motors, one 9G servo for tilting and one 28BYJ-48 stepper motor with driver board.

The whole thing works on a USB powerbank and when starting the red LED lits up. Be sure to have your GoPro WiFi on and when the Witty can connect to it, it sets the GoPro mode to photo and the LED turns green. Pressing the button on the Witty starts the capture process (LED gets red) and making 6 pictures over 360 degree and then tilting the camera up for the last picture. When it is done it returns the platform to the start position so that the wires don't get twisted.

I use the QS-29 mount for my tripod, use the hole under the stepper to connect them together.

Use some M3x8 mm screws for the stepper driver PCB and to secure the stepper motor.

Demo video: https://youtu.be/ar1DtjWEi8k
First demo image: http://www.pixelmagic.nl/pano2.html

Update may 6 2016: added Arduino program PixelPano.zip to the project. Beware: I am not a professional programmer and when stuff blows up don't start blaming me !

print_settings.Notes:: I printed this on my Play, using CURA, with supports-to-bed only.  If you use supports everywhere, it might fill in the hole where the filament goes, and you'd have a hard time removing that support material.  I used 80% fill, but I could probably have gotten away with less.  Print time about 25 minutes

description.text: This is a simple filament guide which helps to keep the filament aligned to the extruder if you are using a non-stock spool holder. It just kind of snaps in place on the play's metal frame, and you can use it on the left side or the right side. I designed it to go with my Adjustable Width Spool Holder (found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1479544). I was having issues with the spool binding, and getting pulled onto the print bed, but this guide has helped to remediate that, and it hasn't happened again so far (fingers crossed!). Note that if you use it with that spool holder, you need to orient the spool so that it spins counterclockwise.

Notes:

I printed this on my Play, using CURA, with supports-to-bed only. If you use supports everywhere, it might fill in the hole where the filament goes, and you'd have a hard time removing that support material. I used 80% fill, but I could probably have gotten away with less. Print time about 25 minutes
I ran a drill bit through the filament hole after printing, just to clean up the inside of the hole so that the filament goes through smoothly.

Note -You need support material in order to print this key-chain. When sizing to your print bed it works great at a scale of .25 (2 1/5 inches) or .3 (3 inches)

This gear is 3 separate pieces but prints as one item. It based off of a herringbone gear, but to increase contact points, I offset the top and bottom set of teeth. Once all the support material is dissolved and removed the gear spins very smooth.

I used Autocad 2016 to design this piece, first experimenting with herringbone gears, then changing the way the gears are arranged. Next I wanted a way to test this, and make it have a purpose. so I started to design a case around the two gears. to ensure the piece could be more sturdy when using as a key-chain, so designed so the gear could print freely inside of the case.

description.text:
Dude, your phone is levitating?!

"Freischwinger" is German and translates to "free swinging".

I wanted to make a simple design with clear forms & edges. This stand is reduced down to its fundamentals yet provides a save and secure resting place for your mobile device.

There are two versions available:

title: Infinite Castle Expansion 1:Buildings & Dungeons
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've only posted models for corner clip and svg bmp files for laser cutting and engraving .The entire download is available for free after a simple email/newsletter registration at

https://timeportalgames.com/wp/free-stuff/
see blog release at
https://timeportalgames.com/wp/
This is an expansion set for my open source Infinite Castle Design.
The castle is constructed from 3d print pieces and laser cut/engraved foam and wood parts. This expansion features a bunch of 3d printed "clips" that allow for you to make various sizes of buildings with windows and doors. The clips can also be used to design dungeons.
This is a 3d print/ laser cut mash up. It is a 28mm fort/castle.

Printer:

Power Spec & Makerfarm

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

.15

Notes:

Any single extruder printer will do, very few parts even require supports

Laser cutting and video

You can use any texture you want for laser cutting.Floors are laser cut in one pass using 1/8th inch baltic birch ply . Shingles are cut from 2mm depron foam. Window and door slots in foam are hand cut but you could integrate this into your design. BMP images are raster engraved twice. Once with a half tone dither and once with no dither and a b/w threshold of 90 or so. Walls are laser engraved XLPE and EVA foam. It is laser engraved with a 40w laser at 100% speed and 75% power using no dither @250 DPI. It is important not to increase resolution higher as that actually doubles the cutting power of the laser. Below is a preview video, it is low-fi, long, and boring so lower your expectations if you want to watch it.

https://youtu.be/HlDAUe1IFkw
The selfdrawing painting!
Never get bored by your current painting! any time, any place and any color as you wish. you can let it paint whatever you want! This machine had loads, loads of prototypes. Mine is controlled by an arduino UNO with CNC shield and GRBL controller, but you can use anything that you want that reads G-codes of NC-files. For making the G-code or NC-file you can use your normal 3D slicer or (what I prefer) Inkskape with the laserengraver extension.

Bill of extra materials; (apart of the printed parts)
-sheet of wood 375x600mm
-a steel plate(or glass,whatever you prefer)
-2x 8mm smooth rod 595mm long
-2x 8mm smooth rod 350mm long
-2x M8 treated rod 420mm long
-2x nema 17 stepper motor
-2x 608zz (skate) bearing
-1x 624zz bearing
-4x LM8UU linear bearing
-around 2meter of timing belt
-2 pulleys (for on the stepper motors)

-15x M3x16 bolt
-4x M8 nut
-1x M4x20
-3xM3 nut
-some whasers to make sure that the belt won't dislocate
-some tyraps

THE SELFDRAWING PAINTING

Ever had a wall that bored you? Do you have some technical skills that you want to test?
There is a DIY solution for you!
You are going to make an painting that writes on itself.It is based on a 3D printer/CNC milling machine. But instead it does not make anything, it draws something!
The whole frame is already designed for you, it is up to you to finish the last bit!
The assembly only takes about one hour and you only have to use some basic tools like allan-keys, some wrenches and a cutter.

This is going to be the result. Step 1

Step one is probably the hardest one. Getting all the parts.
Most of the parts can be printed with a basic printer (120x120mm)
the rest can be bought at your hardware store.
There is only one exception; The lazercutted plate. Not everyone has the luxury to have one at their disposal.

Step 2

The assembly.
The assembly is quite straight forward, you can see an exploded view of all the parts on the picture below.
I recommend to clamp the lasercutted wood with the printed parts, the smooth rods and the treated rod first.
once you assembled the outer-frame, continue by building the x/y component bij mounting the two NEMA 17 stepper motors.
afterwards, place the pulley's,smooth rods, bearings and bolts. Tighten the bolts and secure the linear bearings if needed.

Exploded view of all the parts The X/Y component assembled Step 3

The electronics...
As almost every Reprap 3D printer, there is no tutorial how to do the electronics. This is because everyone as another way of doing it. There are many, many ways of doing it.
The challenge is up to you to find the easiest way to control it.
Goodluck!

comments.text: Thank you for the quick response. Yes the drawing makes perfect sense. Can you also please show/describe how the y-idler assembly is created? Are you using a bearing on a press-fit dowel in the 3D printed part or some other way with a timing pulley? Also, method of attachment of belt to y-carriage (do I zip ties?).  Rough hand sketches will work - no need for CAD. Thanks.
comments.author: OliviersHappyCreations

comments.text:
The y-idler works with m3 & m4 screws. The bearing (624zz) is mounted in the middle of the y-idler with an m4 screw. The belt should go around the bearing and the washer should hold it in place. The two m3 screws go through the top of the idler and should have a nut on the inside. These two bolts are used for tightening the belt by pushing the linear axes outwards.
I have added some pictures, those might be handy.

This is a PostScript program to generate optical encoder wheels. Unlike other encoder generator programs, it is highly flexible and has many features, such as:
  • Correct inside and outside diameters, regardless of line width.
  • Quadrature capabilities, with adjustable phase difference.
  • Automatic scaling of text size.
  • Optional index track, with adjustable size or automatic fitting to segment size.
  • Automatic page filling with cutting allowances.
  • Most features can be turned on or off.

To use, open up the file in a text editor and edit the settings. Then, open the file in a PostScript viewer (Acrobat?, Okular) or interpreter (GhostScript, ps2pdf) and print it out.
If you find any bugs, please email me. My address is in the file.
For best results, use the latest version. Changelog

v1.4 (latest) Added page size options. v1.3 Corrected bug caused by me being idiot about how quadrature actually works. I was calculating the phase difference based on one segment, but two segments actually make up a full wave, so the quadrature came out as half of the PhaseDifference. Many thanks to Rafael Pinto for finding this. v1.2 Corrected bug causing a 1 degree gap in the segment track at extremely high segment counts (>700). v1.1 Corrected bug causing letter descenders (such as on g,j,p,q, and y) to be drawn on and below the underLine. Letter descenders are now placed above it. v1.01: Corrected typos in code comments.

title: RTM X End Clamp, for the Ronthomp Mendel

description.text:
This is a simplification. I added the Z stop bolt mount to the X end clamp, eliminating a printed part, some hardware and a source of failure. My clip on Z stop is easy to move accidentally.
The bolt is a 6-32 x 2" and is tightened against the trapped nut. (4mm works, too.) The Z home is easily and accurately adjusted by moving the thumb nut. One turn of the 6-32 screw is .03125"
The thumb nut is self threading when you screw it on, just keep it straight.
The clamp still uses the M3 nuts in 4 places and either a M8 or 5/16" nut to match your Z lead screw.
Refer to the old version to see the improvement:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13235

Print the parts. Assemble like the photos. Screw the thumb nut on half way to start, so you have plenty of adjustment up or down.
Adjust your switch mount by eye as close as you can, then fine adjust with the thumb nut as needed.

comments.text: Your part needs a diaphragm on the extension you made to the part.  When printing, it goes from hex head, to just an inner circle and the plastic just squirts right in the hole.  So the one I printed just plain didn't turn out right.  That's ok because there's plenty of plastic left over to drill a hole into and work from there so it wasn't a total loss.

title: UDOO case

description.text:
Hello to all!
I decided to publish this homes to mini computer endebded udoo. The official website of the board is www.udoo.org .
The design of the board was given by my professor of drawing A.T. as homework that we had given the newly introduced and the construction of a box for the board.
After you draw it I also printed and I have to say that it came good! :-)
If you have questions write me and I will be happy to answer you.
goodbye by green.pixel .

what you have need to complete this case:
  • a 4.5 x 10 cm iron grid
  • 5 screws for fixing the cap
  • 6 screws for fixing the UDOO
  • some hot glue
  • and a UDOO!!!!!!

comments.text:
I have the same issue as ="patola:disqus" href="http://disqus.com/Patola/Patola.
I have a quadcore udoo and the case is just too tight. When I am
finally able to squeeze everything in somewhat close the power input
does not line up.
comments.author: 360linux

comments.text: It doesn't work. I printed your case and then tried to fit in my UDOO - the dimensions are exact, so there is no room for the dangling parts of the connectors. I tried reprinting it with 1% increase in size and it sort of squeezed into the case, but it almost broke. 2% increase might be ideal, but I already lost two cases and a good amount of filament.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text:
I ran into the same problems trying to fit my Udoo dual. I was thinking about reprinting at 102%, but I think the design is flawed. The connector positions may vary from unit to unit, but between the protruding ports on the front and the switches sticking out on the side, it's impossible to angle the board in without damaging something. What it probably needs is the faceplate for the main connectors merged with the lid.
I do really like this designs lid, using the logo for venting (and the screen was a nice touch).
comments.author: Patola

comments.text:
It's not my problem! I can only say that: instead of print 3 cases you could file the part more.
Anyway, my udoo inside would fit perfectly (I can just insert a photo for confirmation).
Your udoo is original?
Your printer is calibrated well?
P.S. I invite you to click on "I Made One" and post the pictures.
If you think that my project is not good, post one yourself, always remembering that it is licensed under "Creative Commons - Attribution - No Derivatives"

I am trying. First and foremost, thank you for your design. I think I expressed myself badly, and that is because I was sort of frustrated after printing for the second time.
I increased the case a little and also thickened some divisions on the side with the most openings (since they are so thin, it was common for the printer nozzle to stumble on the part and make it collapse). I am thinking about separating this part with several holes from the rest and make it attachable. It would make much easier to insert UDOO in it.

comments.text: Barelkodotcom's Nema 17 steppers 40mm fan Mount was an important part I needed to aid in cooling my Witbox's Z stepper. It is very simple, and very effective for my application. title: Euro power strip clip for wall or desk mounting

description.text:
Fits the kind of power strips that you can buy at Clas Ohlson in Norway.

Of course you don't need 3 screws to mount each bracket, but can use whichever holes are convenient. Holes are sized and countersunk to work well with drywall anchor/bolts, or wood or drywall screws.

powerstrip-wall-mount-wide-opening.stl will not cover any of the outlet openings, whereas powerstrip-wall-mount.stl will, but grips the power strip better. So it's good to print one of each, and use the non-wide version at the corded end of the power strip.

title: Junkers Ju-52 simplified cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Junkers Ju-52, also called "Tante Ju" or "Iron Annie" was first build in the early 1930s. The corrugated duralumin metal skin and the three radial engines are the main features. There are still some planes out there flying.

My build was done on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft from 6 mm beech plywood using a spiral-toothed 1.2 mm flute. Glued together and nicely sanded it's a great toy for boys (of different age).
A laser cutter might be a good alternative tool to create smaller versions.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/Spielsachen/Flugzeugmodelle for more designs.

Keep in mind, that the obj-file is just for validating the construction and viewing in the browser.

I took 3-view drawings of this plane from wikipedia to save the tracing, then used Illustrator to carve out the main features. The slots were a result of trail and error. Before building the plane I did a 3D validation in SketchUp. Then I nested the parts as close as possible for production on a cnc-router.

description.text: These are professional name tags that can be designed for any business. There is no real function for these parts, they are just for looks. I made them because i take pride in my business and the way we present ourselves.

These name tags are printed on 3mm acrylic. I used a laser to both engrave and cut them out. They are simple parts that anyone could make, there are no critical features. I made these parts by creating five rectangles and lining them up. Then I added three text lines inside the rectangles and used them to personalize them. I raster cut with a speed of 100 and a power level of 60. Then I vector cut with a speed of 10 and a power level of 100 and set the vector frequency to 5,000.

Just a simple remix of the head part of the Axe Rattle, added in a barrior between the handle and and head Seals the axe head in. (so you add the rattle peas in while its halfway printed. )

Adds a little safety in case the axe head comes off the handle, the peas will stay sealed within the axe head.

Working on printing on now, will upload pic when its done :D

author: dfoles

title: Lewihe Play belt grip for X carriage AKA 'Bad boy'

description.text:
This is an alternate X carriage for a better/easier belt grip. In a coreXY printer, a balanced belt tension is essential. I felt a bit difficult to do this task with the factory part. I designed this to be able to pre-tensioning with ease. By the way you can add something more like a cable clamp, LED support, belt securing with some screw/washer, etc. I like more this part than the factory one, it was cool, but I like to do things on my own way. When the pic was taken I wasn't wearing my glasses and fitted the right upper belt the wrong way heheh... I was wondering why it was so hard to push it inside.... Remember, in a coreXY setup ALL the belts have its teeth in the same direction on the extruder part. Recommended printing ABS at least 0.4mm nozzle and 0.2mm layer.

UPDATE (30-MAY-2016): New pics.

UPDATE (22-MAY-2016): For those of you having problems inserting the wires I have enhanced/widened the internal wormhole. Now wire inserting is a breeze...

UPDATE (10-MAY-2016): Ok Ok. Increased wormhole dimensions. Changed pivot to include a hole for the zip ties. Anything more?

UPDATE (18-MAY-2016): Added a new model with wormholes to conduct inwards the fan wires to a top pivot where a zip tie can be used to attach all cables in a cleaner design (Extruder fan & layer fan). Doesn't need support. Otherwise similar to the previous model. I am planning a little update to my setup using IGUS drylin RJMP-01-06 (LM6UU type) to try to make the whole thing less noisy and have also taken the time to enhance this. I am also printing all the X carriage and extruder parts in black ABS because while working/messing with the machine I always stain my nice shiny white parts, so that being black I hope that future stains will be less visible. It's a pity that shiny white parts only have that wonderful look the first few days of work... Hint: you can use some nylon thread as a guide to conduct the wires along the wormholes, just in case. Although fan wires are usually thin enough to be entered manually into the wormholes. I put the pivot away from the bowden adapter to keep separate the wires and the PTFE tube, this way you can operate the tube/bowden without messing with the wires. Remember you will deal much more with the tube than the wires, so keep them away and secure. Wires and PTFE tube follow separate ways in my setup due to this reason.

title: LM8UU ToM - 8mm Rod Adapter Kit for Makerbot

description.text:
I am building a new ToM and I just have 8mm rod and LM8UU leftover from my Prusa Mendal. So I design an adapter kit to convert Makerbot from using 3/8" rod and bushing to 8mm rod and LM8UU linear bearing.
It will fit on standard wood ToM and work pretty well on my new acrylic tom too.

X-stage: Print two pair of X-rodCoverInner/Outer parts for two side of x-stage.
Print one X-support-Lm8uu and snap two LM8UU and 3 nuts in to part.
Print one Xrod_mount_623_8mm and bolt three 623 Bearing on this part. This part is modify from carmiac's X-Axis Follower (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8162) Y-stage: Print 8 of YZ-rodCoverInner and press 4 nuts into one side. This part will install in the inner part of rod end. Print one of Y-Lm8uu vertically. Remove bottom and inner support wall. The part should be symmetrical. Put two LM8UU into parts clamp this part in the Y-stage. Print one of Y-support_8mm. Install three 624 bearing and three nuts on the part. Z-stage: Print two of Z-Lm8uuHolder. Use 8~9mm drill to clear middle wall. Snap two LM8UU one top and bottom.

description.text:
This is a custom support made to fit E3D V6 Hot End for the Hatchbox Alpha. You will need four 5-40 Socket head Machine Cap Screw 1-1/4", and nuts. Two screws connect the support to the delta arm, and two screws connect the support to the hot end.

The Hatchbox Alpha firmware is included. The firmware needs to be compiled and uploaded with Arduino IDE 1.6.5 (will not compile with later versions).

In the firmware you will find the file configuration.h, and you have to search for
(#define EXT0_TEMPSENSOR_TYPE) and change the value to (8). This is the correct value for the E3D V6 Hot end.

I could not get the E3D thermistor to work properly using Repetier's temp controller Deadtime (default on the Alpha). I switched the controller in the configuration menu on the Alpha LCD to controller PID instead.

You will need to perform an extruder PID tuning using command M303 E0 P180 C3 in your slicer. Take the average of each iteration and put the values of kp, ki and kd and add them to the P, I and D value for the controller. Leave Max and Min values at 230 and 40.

The E3D V6 is printing wonderfully, and I was able to print PLA, ABS, PETG and Ninja Flex with great results.

Printer:

Hatchbox Alpha

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Use ABS at recommended settings by the manufacturer.

comments.author: avatar2x

comments.text: Like I said, Hatchbox has added a bunch of custom code to the Repetier Firmware. It is mostly targeted at the interface and auto leveling code. Trying to use Repetier's firmware configuration tool will cause it to fail. I can't find a way around this. When you compile the Hatchbox stock firmware change EEPROM_Mode = 2 in the configuration.h file. This will copy the setting in the configuration.h file to your EEPROM. If you leave it = to 1 it will keep your old EEPROM data. This is in case you accidentally changed something in the EEPROM like delta_max_radius or something. My Alpha will some times move off the glass while auto leveling if the USB is plugged into a computer. I always disconnect the USB while auto leveling.
comments.author: ebross

comments.text: Are you familiar with compiling Python scripts? Yes, I'm currently using the Firmware Hatchbox sent me. If you try to compile with a newer version of Repetier it will fail. Hatchbox has inserted custome code in their firmware. You have to use the one I supplied and make changes to it only.
comments.author: ebross

comments.text: I've forked the Repetier firmware at the commit that Hatchbox pulled from and then overlaid the Hatchbox changes. I've been able to walk the Hatchbox Alpha firmware up several release points as I carefully merge Repetier commits onto my fork. I've been able to build at each merge point and do a successful Auto level test (power off/on the printer after uploading the firmware). I started running simple prints in between some of my later merges, which have been of fairly good consistency. I'm now running a build that is merged up to the current commit on Repetier master. Please note, I've been removing some of the Hatchbox features when I've found Repetier commits that provide similar functionality, e.g. Changing filament. The menus have changed a bit, and you can build using a more recent version of Arduino.

remixed_from.title: NUT JOB | Nut, Bolt, Washer and Threaded Rod Factory

description.text:
The Bigbox heated bed is a 300x200 bed backed with cork and is supported at each corner. Alas, it sags a small amount toward the center. These are designed to provide a little support at three positions underneath the center of the bed.

Fully closed, the bolt will be 22mm. The bed itself is around 25mm distant from the platform below, but could be slightly lower or higher as a result of levelling using the corner spacers. Unscrew this slightly to fit your needs; it should happily support as low as 22mm or as high as 28mm.

Printer:

E3D Bigbox

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

12%

Notes:

I chose a 12% rectilinear grid for the fill, and 3 outlines to give strength to the rod while twisting. I don't recommend printing at 100% as this will create a lot of strain in the part as it's made, probably leading to warping. This is not a heavy duty requirement, we're just pushing the bottom of the heated bed up to the glass in the center.

You could print at a finer resolution, but this is a hidden part. Your choice.

remixed_from.title: Bowden Bracket for Gregs or Wades Extruders

title: Bowden Bracket for Gregs or Wades Extruders - Mcmaster Fittings - 3mm

description.text:
Hey folks,   
I had trouble coming across Pneufit fittings to run a bowden system on my prusa, so I modified Stu_Dkn's "Bowden Bracket for Gregs or Wades Extruders" to work with fittings from McMaster-Carr.   
The fittings, specifically, that I am using are item number 5449K173 for the fittings,  52335K53 for the polypropaline 5mm OD 3mm ID tubing for the bowden itself.   
The enlarged hole may require some manual chamfering or a tap to be run into it in order for a snug fit with the fitting. Once the threads are started, the tapered nature of the plug will seat it in nicely.  
Enjoy!
